titleStmt.title: Joseph Dalton Hooker an Alexander von Humboldt. Darjeeling, 25. Juli 1848, mit Nachschrift vom 28. Juli 1848

physDesc.p: Johann Friedrich Klotzsch fertigte von Blatt 13 und 14 eine Abschrift für Alexander von Humboldt an, auf der dieser ausführliche Anmerkungen notierte. Diese Abschrift ist als Blatt 19 und 20 zusammen mit dem Brief im Nachlass überliefert und hier am Ende des Briefes ediert. Die orthographischen Fehler wurden nicht korrigiert. Eine Paraphrase der Inhalte von Bl. 13 ging in die 3. Auflage von Humboldts „Ansichten der Natur“ ein (Humboldt 1849, I, 125–126). Zudem fügte Klotzsch dem Brief eine Blattzählung in roter Tinte hinzu.

listWit.witness: Hooker, J. D. 1849, 230–242 und Tafel II am Ende des Bandes ohne Seitenzählung (Übersetzung)

correspDesc.note: Der Brief enthält eine Nachschrift vom 28. Juli 1848 von Joseph Dalton Hooker.

div.p:
I again do myself the honor
of availing myself of the kind privilege you
allowed me of addressing you; & this at
last from the Himalayah. May this
letter find you in continued health &
vigor.

On my arrival in Calcutta with Lord
Dalhousie I found that the Thibet
Mission was broken up; the Chinese
having sent no Commissioners to meet
those of our Govt Government , & being more jealously
than ever opposed to any European
crossing their frontier. I resolved at once
to commence an exploration of the Cis-
Himalayan regions. As the season was
still very early I took an excursion on
the plains, which has not been wholly
unprofitable. Proceeding West from
Calcutta, I joined M Mister
William ’s s’ (of the
Coal Survey) camp in Burdwan district
& visited the coal fields. These are certainly
in extent & position only to be compared
with the carboniferous period of Europe;
their fossils must on the whole be regarded
as equally dissimilar from those of the
oolite or carboniferous period, are allied
to what I have seen in the Australian fields
2.& possibly indicate their belonging to an
Epoch which had no equivalent (chrono
logical) in the more Northern Latitudes.
From the coal fields I ascended a lofty
Granitic Table land forming part of a
system which crosses India from the
Gulf of Cambey to the junction of the
Hughli & Ganges. This is generally
considered a part of the Vindhya, but
I take it to be a different range
parallel to the latter, joining it in
Central India, at Omer-Kuntuk the
water shed of the Soane & Nerbudda,
& again seperating separating it pursues a still
parallel course dividing the Nerbudda
from the Taptee. The Vindhya are a
sandstone range from Chunar its N.E. North East
extreme on the Ganges to Omerkuntuk 4500 ft. feet :
the range I crossed first Gneiss &
Granitic from
the Hughli to the same (Omer Kuntuk). Thence
W. West to the Gulf of Cambey both are
overlain by trap, but the Southern
range is still Granitic at heart? &
joins the great Ghat range which
runs S. South to Cape Comorin. The Vindhya
again .
are continuous with the sandstone
of the Rajpootan hillsVermutlich ist das Aravalligebirge gemeint. Rajputana wurde die Region des heutigen Rajasthan zur Zeit von Britisch-Indien genannt., Mt. Mount Aboe & all
the central & W. Western districts. For the 120
miles of the Granite range I traversed the mean
3.height was 1200 ft. feet – with Granite
hills of 3000 rising above it – one of
the latter I ascended was 4050 ft. feet above
the sea & the great seat of Jain worship
in the East, as Mt. Mount Aboe is in the West
of India. The Jains who worship
Parus Nath are certainly a transition
sect between Buddhists & Brahmins.

On these hills are scattered tribes of a
very different race origin , the Kols & Bheels
of central India; a very timid race, who
segregate themselves from one another
& all other people. These are no doubt,
like the numerous scattered tribes along
the base of the Himalayah, the remote
parts of the Vindhya, the GhatsDie Westghats und Eastghats des indischen Subkontinents. of the
Peninsula &c: – all remains of the
original Tamulian stock, who ever
since the Arian Invasion, have retained
a position in the fastnesses of the mountains
& malarious jungles. Such is the opinion
of my friend Mr. Hodgson, undoubtedly
the best authority on these subjects & who
is now collecting vocabularies of all
these scattered tribes throughout India. A
noble work which none is better able to
perform.

Proceeding West: the descent from the
Granitic (Gneiss, Hornblende, Schist &c) plateau
to the plains through which the Soane
flows is sudden, from 1300 to 600 ft feet .
This plain, 80 or 100 miles broad &
level with the bed of the Ganges,
isolates the Sandstone range of the
Vindhya from that of Paras-Nath
(the culminant peak on the Granitic
plateau). Crossing the Soane Erannoboas (Hieiramo
boas) about 50 miles above its mouth
(the undoubted site of Palibothra), the
Vindhya range rise abruptly (called
here the Kymaor) & present an abrupt
escarpment 1200 ft feet above the plain of
horizontal sandstones overlying a
thick bed of non-fossiliferous limestone.

Their wooded summits form another
table-land equal in height with
the Granitic plateau, covered with a
similar vegetation, but nowhere rising
into hills, they are peopled by a very
scattered tribes of Kols & Bheels who
work the Iron found scattered over their
summits.Though resting on limestone
this sandstone is nowhere carboniferous
& I suspect belongs to a very much earlier
period than that of the Indian coal.

From the East extreme of the Vindhya
I turned up the Soane valley for one or
two hundred miles, our march was
very fatiguing owing to the absence
of roads & roughness of the country.
We passed the noble hill forts of
Rhotas & Bidjegur, which occupy
prominent spurs of the range; the
sandstone on one side of the river &
low hills of Hornstone, jasper, quartz
& Porphyry, highly inclined & contorted
on the opposite or Southern bank.
These are beneath the Limestone of
Vindhya & I believe rest on the
granite: they are much altered by
heat & yield the Jaspers & agates
known as Soane Pebbles. Their general
appearance is that of dry naked isolated
hills skirting the Granite formation
from the upper part of the Soane valley,
running N. E. North East to GyaVermutlich ist Gaya gemeint.. – On my passage
down the Ganges I believe I recognize
the same in the Monghyr & Sultanganje
& Colgong-rocks, thus here skirting
the N North flanks of the Granite range &
causing the Ganges to take a long sweep
6.to the East. Near Bhangulpore I
procured agates precisely similar to
those of the Soane, which had been
employed in the decoration of some
ruined Jain temples &c near that
Town. –

During my travels up the Soane I
ascended the Vindhya several times
Botanizing, Geologizing & taking
Meterological Meteorological observations: & finally
leaving the valley above Bidjeghur
I crossed the Vindhya & descended to
the Ganges at Mirzapur. With the
Barometer I have levelled this
whole route. I carefully noted its
indications 4 times a day, with those of
the Therm. Thermometer
, Black bulb- Therm. Thermometer , Photometer
& Hygrometer. At night I determined
the amount of radiation both of a
naked exposed Therm. Thermometer
& others laid on
the ground, grass &c.A really magni
ficent aurora was the finest meteor
I saw. & of this an account appeared in
the Indian & European papers. Solar
radiation I find much more powerful
than it was ever supposed to be in these
7.Latitudes, or than I ever observed it
to be in the Tropical seas. Even in the
month of February I have obtained results
quite opposed to the published conclusions
on this subject. The extraordinary dryness
of the air on the table-land is extr very
remarkable. 0.387. being the mean
amount of moisture during 10 days of
February . , & on one occasion at 9 PM. 0.140.
During this period I never saw dew
formed, though the nights were bright
& clear: on the plains however 1000 ft feet
below, though the mean dryness moisture was
0.516 only, dew was always formed.
Nocturnal radiation was the same
amount above & below.

From Mirzapur I took a boat
& descended the Ganges to Bhangulpore,
visiting many interesting citys places on the
route especially Benares, where I visited
the now ruinous observatory; . ( one of the
five built by Jayn-Singh : ) observed
with the famous & examined
the .
The poor Astronomer Royal was a squalid
object, dirty & diseased, who implored
bucksheesh on my departure, saying he
8.was very hungry & that the Ra pr esent
Rajah hardly gave him any-thing
to keep him from starving.

The Sanatorium of Darjeeling being
situated in the least explored part of
the Himalayah, I travelled hither from
Bhangulpore, by land; & shall remain
till the rains are over. The Chinese
will not hear of any traveller crossing
their frontier & the Rajah of Sikhim
is opposed to my exploring in his
territories – I have however visited
both the Nepaul & Bhotan frontier
& hope when the rains are over to
get to the Snowy range. This station
is in the heart of the Sub Himalayah
which rises in forest clad hills all
around to 10 & 14 000 ft feet : forming a
series of short isolated ranges between
the true Snowy range & the plains.
There is no system whatever in this
SubHimalayah, they are all short
ridges running in various directions
divided by steep & deep valleys, through
which the streams from the snow
wind to the plains.Occasionally
9.hills of conglomerate & sandstone
rest on the outer base of subHimalayah,
& there is always a broad bed of
gravel resting on an indurated clay:
sometimes 10 miles broad. The waters
of the many streams percolate through
this, anastomize & render it a swamp,
which is the deadly malarious Terai.
This tract is extremely narrow here
but generally broad, covered with
long Sacchara & other grasses, with
here & there Dalbergia sissoo & other
small trees. The Sal forest (Shorea
robusta) is generally at its inner core
ascending the hills for 2000 ft. feet or
occupying dry spurs of the mts mountains
which project on to the plains.

At 4000 ft. feet tropical forms are replaced
by temperate ones. Rhododendrons are
not in this longitude found below
7000 ft feet ; from above of which I have
12 species, one an epiphyte & sweet
scented with enormous white flowers.
Both E. East & .
W. West of this Rhododendrons
descend to 50 45 00 ft feet & even lower.
The rocks are mica schist with
10. Garnets at the outer base of the
hills – highly contorted & dislocated
bed of Gneiss higher up to 7000 & 11000
ft feet . In the valleys I have visited
N North of this chlorite & quartz slate
& quartz itself. I am inclined to
think that these rocks all pass
into one another here; but so dense
a forest clothes all that it is
difficult to prove this. Though the
valleys are so steep we have hardly
a precipice any where. We have
Limest Limestone depositing springs in the
valleys but none in situ: In Bootan
N Ea st of this,
Mts Mountains wholly of primitive
Limestone are common. I have seen
no Volcanic rocks, but picked up
rolled pebbles in the deep streams of
trap or green stone. In Kemaon
Volcanic rocks are fully developed &
doubtless too in Nepaul & Sikim too
as well as Bhotan.

Darjeeling is elevat elevated
7200 ft: feet on a
ridge or spur of Gneiss looking d North
overlooking a series of many hills of
8-10000 ft feet which, divided by an equal
11.number of deep & steep valleys, intervene
between this place & the Snow. The
latter rises in a grand mass of snowy
peaks, spires, domes & tables topped
hills to the height of 28178 feet.

Last night the Surveyor general who
spent last season here sent us the
results of his measurements as above.
This mountain, the loftiest on the
globe, except Dawalgiri now being
remeasured be higher, is only 42′ off;
it is called Kinchin-jinga.

The measurements were taken from
8 stations, all agreed within 200 feet
& most within much less – two within
one foot of one another. It was a
very long & most admireably admirably conducted
operation. Chamalari, which is
visible from this neighbourhood, is
24000.

There is a curious bend in the
Himalayah
N.E. North East of this, an interruption
of the whole chain in short; so that
I expect Chamalari will prove to
belong to the true range, though
owing to the dislocation of the latter
12.that mountain be isolated. The
subjoined rude sketch may give
some idea of what I mean. – By this
it appears that Chamalari is scarcely
4′ North of the snowy range proper.

div.p:
Your Asie centraleHumboldt 1843. contains the only
trustworthy map of the Thibetan Mt. Mountain system:
t T hese are not my dear friend the words
of flattery, but the unbiassed opinion of
my master in Thibetan Geography & present
kind host, Mr Hodgson; who has deeply
studied the subject. We labor over
the excellent charts of Richter Ritter , D’anville,
& the imperishable work of Klaproth: but
none of these rival yours. Your Himalayah,
Bolor, Kien-lun & the Pelin chain on the
East are the boundaries of that country;
& we only differ in still holding the Himalayah
& not the Kien-lun to be the dividing chain
of Asia. – All your views on the climatology
of Asie centraleHumboldt 1843. are excellent. The Snow
line is indisputably much higher on
the N. North side of the great range, & for the
reasons you assign, great evaporation &
a trifling precipitation. These indeed
are the ruling elements all along the
chain & to this is due the wonderful
fact, that the Snow line descends from
20,000 ft. feet in the transsutledge
Mts Mountains
36 N North (in the N.W. North West ) to 15000 on the
passes South of the Brahma-Putra
between Assam & Birma in 27 !! where
are the Southernmost snowy Mts Mountains in Asia.

div.p:
The course of the Yaru Tsampo is
still a matter of dispute; & consequently
the upper course of the Brahmaputra.
Hodgson inclines to think the Dihong,
Dibong &c ,
defluents of the Tsanpo
which thus divides N. North of the snow &
seeks many courses through that
chain into the Brahma-putra. When
I consider the enormous precipitation
all along the course of the latter river
& that it drains snowy Mts Mountains North,
East & South of its course in upper Assam,
I cannot but suppose that it has
enough to do without receiving the
Tsampo. Does the latter then flow
into the ocean East of the Irrawaddi?
or join the Yanzi kiang? We know
that the Himalaya reaches upper
Assam, but whether the chain is
thence continued East, or turns South,
as the Mishmi &c hills, is still
undetermined, & this probably will
indicate the course of that mysterious
river.

I intend to devote the following
15.Season to Upper Assam & hope by
measuring the waters of the Dihong
& Brahmaputra at Sudiya to gain
some indications. I may too gain
information from the native tribes
but constant wars segregate these
so much that they have not the
means of acquiring information themselves.

Since we have established Tea
plantations & opened a trade with
these tribes, the Chinese have guarded
that frontier with redoubled solici
tude, & except some most unlooked
for event should open a communi
cation with that people I dare not
hope ever to enter Thibet East of
Kemaon.

Mr Hodgson & myself are now
anxious to define some defineable
intelligeable intelligible
regions in the whole length of the
Himalayah so as to indicate the
Botanical & Zoological regions with
more precision than by such vague
terms as Nepaul, Bhotan &c. He
has proposed dividing the chain longi
16. dut tud inally by the obverse deltas the
rivers form, or rather the affluents of
the rivers. Each region will thus
embrace the space between two of
the greater or culminant mountains;
T t hese throw off the water in to the
East & to the West. The Eastern streams
of gu Go ssain-than for instance alt altitude
26000 24,700
ft feet
meeting the Western streams from
Dhavala-Giri together form the
GandacGandaki river, – Gossain Than & Kinchin
junga the Cosi river – Kinchinjung
& Chola or Chamalari give another
watershed, the Tista: Now he can
Zoologically define the Tista valley,
Cosi valley or Gandac
V. Valley & I can
do the same Botanically: so that
we apprehend no difficulty in carrying
out this view.

The Thibet mission as I mentioned
above is broken up, but my intrepid
friend Thomson who explored the
Shayuk in the month of December &
returned by Iskardo to Kashmir, is
allowed to travel another year, & thus
already started for Leh & hopes to cross
17.the Karokoram, he is working admirably.
I think I told you he was my earliest
play-fellow, school & college companion:
we took our degrees & started in life
together, he for India, I for the South
Pole. When I was shut up in the
Ice he was a prisoner in Cabul
suffering the horrors of that captivity,
which so few survived. I need not
say how anxious we are to meet
next year, after a 10 years absence.
Could he have travelled in Yarkand
I would have joined him ere this ; .

The second volume of KosmosHumboldt 1846-1858, II. ,
has
given us the greatest delight: There are
3 copies in Darjeeling! where there are
not 30 European residents — Col Colonel & Mrs
Sabine’s translation is admirable.

The Asiatic Society flourishes here, &
Dr. Doctor
Falconer’s arrival in charge of the gardens
has given a spur to science. They have done
me the honor of making me an honorary
member.

closer.salute:
Accept Hodgson’s profound sentiments
of respect & esteem & with them these of
Your ever grateful & affectionate
servt servant

postscript.p:
You will be sorry to hear that the news
has this day reached me, of my dear Father's
having fallen in the Gardens, dislocated his
shoulder, & lacerated certain ligaments of the
joint.Should you ever see my old friend
Herr Klotzsch will you honor me by conveying
my affectionate regards to him.

P. S. I have reason to believe
that the Snows are accumulating &
the Snow line is descending on the
Himalayah. I will attend to
this subject however.
